freeScreening.title: Free Screening
freeScreening.description: A screening is a brief and informal evaluation to confirm if your child is meeting age-appropriate milestones. Early identification can change your child's developmental path.

content.title: Are you concerned about:
content.concern_3: Ability to play and/or interact with others
content.concern_5: Ability to pay attention and participate in different activities for a period of time
content.call_to_action: Contact us to schedule your complimentary screening

fullAssessment.title: Assessment
fullAssessment.description: An assessment is a detailed and formal evaluation to determine the type and severity of any identified speech or language difficulties.

content.title: If you have concerns about your child’s:
content.concern_1: Receptive Language (understanding language – e.g., words and concepts, following directions, answering questions)
content.concern_2: Expressive Language (communicate wants, needs, feelings, and ideas using gestures, actions, sounds, and words)
content.concern_4: Social Communication (use of verbal and non-verbal language in different social contexts and for different reasons to connect and communicate with others)
content.concern_5: Play skills (appropriate use of variety of toys including pretend/imaginary play)
content.concern_6: Self-regulation (ability to understand and manage own behaviour/reaction to things happening around self)
content.concern_7: Some skills are on track, but others are falling behind or <u>losing any skills</u> at any time
content.concern_8: Something isn’t quite right about any area of your child’s development, but you can’t explain what it is
content.call_to_action: Don’t wait to seek an assessment!

languageTherapy.title: Language Therapy
languageTherapy.description: Addresses children with delays or disorders in the areas of understanding and/or expression of language.

content.title: Understanding and expression of language
content.concern_1: Difficulty comprehending the meaning of words and/or sentences
content.concern_2: Difficulty understanding implied information (i.e., information based on other clues, draw conclusions)
content.concern_3: Limited use of gestures and actions
content.concern_4: Limited use of sounds, words or sentences
content.concern_6: Difficulty understanding and/or knowing how to organize words in a sentence
content.concern2_1: Using limited vocabulary for your child’s age while progressing well in the other areas of development
content.concern2_2: Not having an explanation for this specific delay

socialCommunicationTherapy.title: Social Communication Therapy
socialCommunicationTherapy.description: Social communication is how children use verbal and non-verbal skills to interact with others. Therapy helps them understand and use these skills effectively in social situations.

content.title: Social Communication
content.concern_1: Stopping and looking when your name is called
content.concern_2: Showing and sharing objects of interest with others
content.concern_3: Paying attention to where the adult is looking and pointing
content.concern_4: Using facial expressions, gestures, sounds, and words
content.concern_5: Playing with toys in an appropriate and creative way
content.concern_6: Taking turns when playing and interacting with others
content.concern_7: Interpreting the words and actions of others and responding accordingly
content.concern_8: Making friends and participating in teamwork
content.concern2_1: Difficulty responding to social rules in a specific situation controlling emotions and acting as accepted (i.e., <u>emotional regulation</u>)
content.concern2_2: Difficulty responding to adult support to manage own emotions (i.e., <u>co-regulation</u>)
content.concern2_3: Difficulty maintaining an appropriate level of alertness (not too active or lethargic) and responding in a particular situation (i.e., <u>sensory regulation</u>)
content.concern2_4: Difficulty problem solving, paying attention, and staying on the current task (i.e., <u>cognitive regulation</u>)

articulationTherapy.title: Articulation Therapy
articulationTherapy.description: Helps correct difficulties in pronouncing sounds and words to improve speech clarity.

content.title: Articulation/Pronunciation
content.concern_1: Difficulty saying speech sounds or word correctly and clearly
content.concern_2: Changing a sound, leaving out a sound or part of a word, substituting one sound for another

faq.title: FAQ
faq.subtitle: Look Here
faq.description: Find answers to the most common questions about speech therapy services and how we can help your child.

question1.question: What is Talk & Bloom?
question1.answer: Talk & Bloom is a pediatric speech-language pathology practice established in Thornhill, Ontario. We provide speech, language, and social communication therapy. Services are provided in English and Spanish.

question2.question: When to see a speech and language therapist?
question2.answer: If you’re concerned about your child’s communication skills at any age, it’s best to have a screening or an assessment completed by a speech and language therapist as soon as possible. Early identification and treatment lead to best outcomes.

question3.question: How do I choose a private speech and language therapist?
question3.answer: In Ontario, Canada, all speech-language pathologists (SLP) must be registered with the College of Audiologists and Speech Language Pathologists of Ontario (CASLPO). You may visit the CASLPO website to find a qualified SLP, that practices in your city, and who speaks your language. It’ll also help you find the therapy that best matches your child’s needs. Additionally, you can use your favorite search engine or virtual assistant. Remember to type keywords specifically related to what you need help with (e.g., pronunciation, social skills, etc.)

question4.question: Do I need to be referred by a doctor?
question4.answer: No. A doctor’s referral is not needed to access private speech and language therapy. You may book a screening or an assessment directly. Some insurance companies require a doctor’s referral to pay for your private speech therapy. Please check with your individual provider.

question5.question: Is speech therapy covered by OHIP and by private insurance?
question5.answer: Unfortunately, OHIP doesn’t cover private speech therapy. Many extended health care plans do. Please check with your insurance company to confirm their specific criteria to pay for your speech and language therapy. Speech therapy is also considered a tax-deductible medical expense. Please check how to claim eligible medical expenses on your tax return.

question6.question: What are your service fees?
question6.answer: Our national Speech-Language & Audiology organization (SAC) sets the standard rates. Talk & Bloom fees fall under these standards.
